From: Hamid Ahmadi <Hamid.Ahmadi@chalhoub.com <mailto:Hamid.Ahmadi@chalhoub.com> > 
Sent: Thursday, 3 April 2025 2:33 PM
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com <mailto:dee.deu@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: FW: Cyber BIA Insurance Questions - Action Required

 

Hi Dee,

Please see below responses to the questions requested for cyber insurance.

 

1.	Confirmed EDR solution is enabled on all endpoints and servers
2.	We are using SD-WAN capabilities which provide us with network segmentation and applies on geographic segmentation. There is no segmentation between brands or business functions.
3.	We have a backup policy and procedure in place. Windows Servers which are on-prem are backed up using Metallic and stored on the cloud and all other backups such as AWS Prod Servers, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and Oracle Cloud Database servers are directly backed up in the cloud.
4.	Patches are deployed across the group following the Service Management Change Management. The request is raised for the patching to take place, this is then reviewed by the Change Advisory Board before being deployed internally. An expedited process is available for patches or changes that are critical. 
5.	‘Confirmation that the answers in the app are applicable to all locations’ -> Unclear on this, please provide more info about the app in question
6.	We do not operate in these three countries nor have our IT Services hosted there.

 

 



 

HAMID AHMADI​​​​

MANAGER ‑ INFORMATION SECURITY (SECURITY OPERATIONS)

M.C.T. FZE

DUBAI

‑

UNITED ARAB EMIRATES

Dear Dee,

 

We have amended the below question as highlighted in red/green: 

 

*	Confirmation that the answers in the app proposal form are applicable to all locations

 

On a different subject, we have gathered some information about the claim statistics for the MENA Region (from one the lead (re)insurers in the region): 

 

 

*	Ransomware paid: The average ransom paid has increased from $1.2m to $2.0m.

 



 

*	Most successful threat actors – Conti and Lockbit

 

*	According to the insurer’s trend report, the top 5 most targeted industries in 2025 were:

	1.	Manufacturing
	2.	Retail
	3.	Professional services
	4.	Construction
	5.	Technology

 

*	Incident root causes

chunks.text:
*	According to the insurer’s trend report, the top 5 most targeted industries in 2025 were:

	1.	Manufacturing
	2.	Retail
	3.	Professional services
	4.	Construction
	5.	Technology

 

*	Incident root causes

	1.	Weak privilege
	2.	Patch failure
	3.	No MFA for remote access
	4.	Weak monitoring
	5.	Weak perimeter
	6.	Over privileged service accounts

 

*	Initial attack vector

	1.	CVE 
	2.	Phishing
	3.	Stolen credentials
	4.	Exposed RDP
	5.	Leaked 3rd party credentials 

 

*	Most common types of accounts compromised:

	1.	User
	2.	Service

 

*	Most popular recovery methods

	1.	Restoring of backups
	2.	Rebuilding 
	3.	Clean systems 
	4.	Decryption key
	5.	Manual data rebuild

 

As per the insurer’s trend report, in March 2025 the total number of victims posted to DLS (dedicated leak sites) tracked by CTI (Cyber Threat Intelligence) was 584, this is roughly in line with February 2025. It brings the total victims for Q1 2025 to 1,944 – the highest seen in a single quarter since the insurer began tracking in 2020. They are seeing a continual rise of RansomHub now tracked as “Ocular Spider”. 

 

Look forward to your feedback on the pending subjectivity. 

 

Thanks and regards,

 

Ashok Peter Eapen Dip CII, FRM

Regional Director, General Insurance (Financial Lines & Engineering)





Nasco Middle East
P.O. Box 62528, Dubai, UAE
T +971 4 351 4292  F +971 4 351 4291  D +971 4 305 1659

Quote

Unquote

*	Most common types of accounts compromised:

	1.	Restoring of backups
	2.	Rebuilding 
	3.	Clean systems 
	4.	Decryption key
	5.	Manual data rebuild

 

As per the insurer’s trend report, in March 2025 the total number of victims posted to DLS (dedicated leak sites) tracked by CTI (Cyber Threat Intelligence) was 584, this is roughly in line with February 2025. It brings the total victims for Q1 2025 to 1,944 – the highest seen in a single quarter since the insurer began tracking in 2020. They are seeing a continual rise of RansomHub now tracked as “Ocular Spider”. 

 

Look forward to your feedback on the pending subjectivity.

*	CFC has recently updated their vendor panel, so we have attached this updated list.

 

 

Dear Hagop,

 

With regard to the rack rates of the incident response panel of CFC, they have replied as below:

 

Quote

 

“The reason for the quoted deductible is not to do with the pre-agreed rates we have in place with our vendors. Given our size and scale and the number of incidents we handle a year (over 3,000), we are able to achieve preferential rates with our vendors as it is in our interest to keep incident response costs and legal costs down just as much as it is the insureds.

 

Over the last few years, the average time we have seen for insureds to be fully recovered following a ransomware event is roughly 3 weeks, indicating the type of losses we usually cover. For clients such as Chalhoub, the intends of the policy is to pick up large, sustained events which can impact them for weeks.”

 

Unquote 

 

Trust these are as per your requirements, and we look forward to hearing from you. 

 

Thanks and regards,

 

Ashok Peter Eapen Dip CII, FRM

*	Confirmation that the answers in the app proposal form are applicable to all locations

 

On a different subject, we have gathered some information about the claim statistics for the MENA Region (from one the lead (re)insurers in the region): 

 

 

*	Ransomware paid: The average ransom paid has increased from $1.2m to $2.0m.

 



 

*	Most successful threat actors – Conti and Lockbit

 

*	According to the insurer’s trend report, the top 5 most targeted industries in 2025 were:

	1.	Manufacturing
	2.	Retail
	3.	Professional services
	4.	Construction
	5.	Technology

 

*	Incident root causes

	1.	Weak privilege
	2.	Patch failure
	3.	No MFA for remote access
	4.	Weak monitoring
	5.	Weak perimeter
	6.	Over privileged service accounts

 

*	Initial attack vector

	1.	CVE 
	2.	Phishing
	3.	Stolen credentials
	4.	Exposed RDP
	5.	Leaked 3rd party credentials 

 

*	Most common types of accounts compromised:

	1.	User
	2.	Service

 

*	Most popular recovery methods

	1.	Restoring of backups
	2.	Rebuilding 
	3.	Clean systems 
	4.	Decryption key
	5.	Manual data rebuild

 

As per the insurer’s trend report, in March 2025 the total number of victims posted to DLS (dedicated leak sites) tracked by CTI (Cyber Threat Intelligence) was 584, this is roughly in line with February 2025. It brings the total victims for Q1 2025 to 1,944 – the highest seen in a single quarter since the insurer began tracking in 2020. They are seeing a continual rise of RansomHub now tracked as “Ocular Spider”. 

 

Look forward to your feedback on the pending subjectivity. 

 

Thanks and regards,

Hi Dee,

Please see below responses to the questions requested for cyber insurance.

 

1.	Confirmed EDR solution is enabled on all endpoints and servers
2.	We are using SD-WAN capabilities which provide us with network segmentation and applies on geographic segmentation. There is no segmentation between brands or business functions.
3.	We have a backup policy and procedure in place. Windows Servers which are on-prem are backed up using Metallic and stored on the cloud and all other backups such as AWS Prod Servers, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and Oracle Cloud Database servers are directly backed up in the cloud.
4.	Patches are deployed across the group following the Service Management Change Management. The request is raised for the patching to take place, this is then reviewed by the Change Advisory Board before being deployed internally. An expedited process is available for patches or changes that are critical. 
5.	‘Confirmation that the answers in the app are applicable to all locations’ -> Unclear on this, please provide more info about the app in question
6.	We do not operate in these three countries nor have our IT Services hosted there.

 

 



 

HAMID AHMADI​​​​

MANAGER ‑ INFORMATION SECURITY (SECURITY OPERATIONS)

M.C.T. FZE

DUBAI
